subsection.title: Mathematical expressions
subsection.p: You should have be able to simplify basic mathematical expressions with variables and know how to solve an equation for a variable. Below are a few examples for your review.

example.title: Evaluate an Expression
example.p: Evaluate 2p + \dfrac{r^2}{3} for p = -1 and r = 4.
Substitute -1 for p and 4 for r, and simplify: 2(-1) + \frac{4^2}{3} = -2 + \frac{16}{3} = \frac{-6}{3} + \frac{16}{3} = \frac{10}{3}\checkmark

example.title: Simplify an Expression
example.p: Combine like terms: 3(2x+5)-4x.
In this case one may remove the parentheses by multiplying out the expression 3(2x+5) so that the like terms may be combined. 3(2x+5)-4x3(2x)+3(5)-4x6x+15-4x(6x-4x)+152x+15 \checkmark

example.title: Solve an Equation
example.p: Solve for x: \dfrac{x}{3}+2=\dfrac{x}{4}

There are many ways to start this problem. If you don't like fractions you may "clear" the denominators by multiplying through both sides of the equation by 12. Then proceed to combine the x's on one side. 12\left(\frac{x}{3} + 2\right) & = 12\left(\frac{x}{4}\right)12\left(\frac{x}{3}\right) + 12(2) & = 3x4x + 24 &= 3x4x + 24 - 3x & = 3x-3xx + 24 & = 0x & = -24\checkmark

example.title: Solve an Equation
example.p: Solve for C: S = C + rC

The equation needs to be rearranged so that C is isolated. This can be done by factoring C out of the right side then dividing by 1+r: S = C + rCS = C(1 + r)\frac{S}{1+r} = C Which may be rewritten in the form: C = \dfrac{S}{1+r} \checkmark

subsection.title: Exponent Properties
subsection.p: Problems with exponents may often be simplified using a few basic exponent properties. For now, exponents represent repeated multiplication. We will use this fact to discover the important properties.

historical.title: World View Note
historical.p: The word exponent comes from the Latin expo meaning out of and ponere meaning place. While there is some debate, it seems that the Babylonians living in Iraq were the first to do work with exponents (dating back to the 23rd century BC or earlier!).

example.title: Multiply a^n times a^m using Exponents
example.p: Multipy a^3 times a^2: a^3a^2 \amp\amp\amp \text{Represent }a^4\text{ and }a^2\text{ as products}(aaa)(aa) \amp\amp\amp \text{Regroup}(aaaaa) \amp\amp\amp \text{Represent the product with an exponent}a^5\amp\amp\amp\text{Our Solution} \checkmark

subsection.p: The product rule of exponents can be used to simplify many problems. This is shown in the following examples.

example.title: Product Rule of Exponents
example.p: Multiply: 3^2\cdot 3^6\cdot 3 \amp\amp\amp \text{Same base \((3)\), add the exponents \(2+6+1\)}3^9 \amp\amp\amp \text{Our Solution}\checkmark

example.title: Product Rule of Exponents
example.p: Multiply: 2x^3 y^5 z \cdot 5x y^2 z^3 \amp\amp\amp \text{Multiply \(2\cdot 5\), add exponents on each of \(x, y\) and \(z\)}10x^4 y^7 z^4 \amp\amp\amp \text{Our Solution}\checkmark

subsection.p: Next, we consider what happens when we divide with exponents.

example.title: Division with Exponents
example.p: Divide: \dfrac{a^5}{a^2} \amp\amp\amp \text{Expand exponents}\dfrac{aaaaa}{aa} \amp\amp\amp \text{Since \(\frac{a}{a} = 1\), each \(a\) in the bottom "cancels" an \(a\) in the top.}aaa \amp\amp\amp \text{Convert to exponents}a^3 \amp\amp\amp \text{Our Solution}\checkmark

example.title: Quotient Rule of Exponents
example.p: Divide: \dfrac{7^5 x^8}{7^4 x^3} \amp\amp\amp \text{Subtract the exponents on like bases, \(5-4 = 1\) and \(8-3=5\)}7^1x^5 \amp\amp\amp \text{Note that \(7^1 = 7\) since there is only one \(7\) to multiply.}7x^5 \amp\amp\amp \text{Our Solution}\checkmark

example.title: Quotient Rule of Exponents
example.p: Simplify: \dfrac{5a^3 b^5 c^2}{2ab^3 c} \amp\amp\amp \text{Subtract exponents on \(a, b\) and \(c\)}\frac{5}{2} a^2 b^2 c\amp\amp\amp \text{Our Solution}\checkmark

subsection.p: A third property we will look at will have an exponent problem raised to a second exponent. This is investigated in the following example:

example.title: Powers with Exponents
example.p: Multiply: \left(a^2\right)^3 \amp\amp\amp \text{This means we have three \(a^2\)'s multiplied together}a^2 \cdot a^2 \cdot a^2 \amp\amp\amp \text{Each }a^2\text{ represent the produce of two }a\text{'s}(aa)(aa)(aa) \amp\amp\amp \text{Three groups of two make six }a\text{'s in all multiplied together}a^6 \amp\amp\amp \text{Our Solution}\checkmark

subsection.p: This property is often combined with two other properties which we will investigate now.

example.title: Powers of Products
example.p: Multiply: (ab)^3 \amp\amp\amp \text{This means we have \((ab)\) three times}(ab)(ab)(ab) \amp\amp\amp \text{Regroup the variables}(aaa)(bbb) \amp\amp\amp \text{The product of three \(a\)'s and three \(b\)'s can be written with exponents}a^3 b^3 \amp\amp\amp \text{Our Solution}\checkmark

subsection.p: A quicker method to arrive at the solution is to take the exponent, 3, and put it on each factor in parentheses, (ab)^3 = a^3b^3. This is known as the power of a product rule of exponents: \text{Power of a Product Rule of Exponents: } (ab)^m=a^m b^m
It is important to be careful to only use the power of a product rule with multiplication inside parentheses. This property does NOT work if there is addition or subtraction inside the parentheses.

historical.title: The First-year's Dream
historical.p: Since the 1940s, mathematicians have described a special situation in which this warning is irrelevant as the First-year's Dream. This situation occurs in a certain number system called a ring of characteristic p. It's been considered bad practice to mention such number systems to first-years students, because in such systems, the rules of exponentiation are too good to be true. For example, the mathematician Saunders Mac Lane believed that a knowledge of (a + b)^2 = a^2 + b^2 in a ring of characteristic 2 would corrupt first-year students of algebra. Fortunately, the only number systems we will work with have characteristic 0, in which case (a + b)^0 = a^0 + b^0, a.k.a., 1=1. But we already knew that, didn't we?

assemblage.title: WARNING
assemblage.p:
The Power of a Product Rule only applies to products. It does not apply to sums for any exponent not equal to 1. For example, (1+2)^2 = 3^2 = 9 \amp\amp 	ext{But,}1^2+2^2 = 1+4 = 5 \amp\amp 	ext{So, }(1+2)^2 
eq 1^2+2^2 \amp\amp 	ext{The rule does not hold for a sum.}(a+b)^m
e a^m+b^m \amp\amp\amp 	ext{These are NOT equal if \(m
e 1\), beware of this error!}

subsection.p: Another property that is very similar to the power of a product rule is considered next.

example.title: Powers of Quotients
example.p: Divide: \left(\frac{a}{b} \right)^3 \amp\amp\amp \text{This means we have the three copies of the fraction multiplied together}\left(\frac{a}{b} \right) \left(\frac{a}{b} \right) \left(\frac{a}{b} \right) \amp\amp\amp \text{Regroup the bases}\frac{aaa}{bbb} \amp\amp\amp \text{Multiply fractions across the top and bottom}\dfrac{a^3}{b^3} \amp\amp\amp \text{Our Solution}\checkmark

subsection.p: The power of a power, product and quotient rules are often used together to simplify expressions. This is shown in the following examples:

example.title: Simplify Exponents
example.p: Simplify. (x^3y)^4 \amp\amp\amp \text{Apply the exponent }4\text{ to each factor}(x^3)^4 y^4 \amp\amp\amp \text{Multiply powers}x^{12} y^4 \amp\amp\amp \text{Our Solution}\checkmark

assemblage.title: WeBWorK: Entering Multi-digit Exponents
assemblage.p: If your exponent has two or more digits, you must place parentheses around it. Otherwise, WeBWorK only takes the first number after the ^ as the exponent: Type x^(12) for x^{12}.

example.title: Simplify Exponents
example.p: Simplify. \left(\dfrac{a^3 b}{c^4 d^5} \right)^2 \amp\amp\amp \text{ }\dfrac{(a^3)^2 b^2}{(c^4)^2 (d^5)^2} \amp\amp\amp \text{ }\dfrac{a^6 b^2}{c^8d^{10}} \amp\amp\amp \text{Our Solution}\checkmark

subsection.p: An expression such as 5^3 does not mean we multiply 5 by 3, rather we multiply three 5's together, 5 \cdot 5 \cdot 5 = 125. This is shown in the next example.

example.title: Simplify Exponents
example.p: Simplify. (4x^2 y^5)^3 \amp\amp\amp \text{}4^3 (x^2)^3 (y^5)^3 \amp\amp\amp \text{}4^3 x^6 y^{15} \amp\amp\amp \text{Evaluate \(4^3=4\cdot 4\cdot 4\)}64x^6 y^{15} \amp\amp\amp \text{Our Solution}\checkmark

subsection.p: Never multiply a base by the exponent. In the previous example we did not put the 3 on the 4 and multipy to get 12, this would have been incorrect. These properties pertain to exponents only, not bases.
In this lesson we have discussed five different exponent properties. These rules are summarized in the following table:

row.cell: Power of a Power Rule of Exponents
Power of a Product Rule of Exponents
Power of a Quotient Rule of Exponents

subsection.p: These five properties are often mixed up in the same problem. Often there is a bit of flexibility as to which property is used first. However, order of operations still applies to a problem. For this reason it is our suggestion to simplify inside any parentheses first, then simplify any exponents (using power rules), and finally simplify any multiplication or division (using product and quotient rules).
These problems can quickly become quite involved. Remember to follow order of operations as a guide, simplify inside parenthesis first, then power rules, then product and quotient rules.

subsection.title: Negative Exponents
subsection.p: A few exponent properties deal with exponents that are not positive. The first is considered in the following example, which is worked out two different ways:

example.title: Investigate Zero Power

subsection.p:
This result is an important property known as the Zero Power Rule of Exponents: \text{Zero Power Rule of Exponents: } a^0=1
Any number (except 0) or expression raised to the zero power will always be 1. This is illustrated in the following example.

example.title: Zero Power Rule of Exponents
example.p: Simplify. (3x^2)^0 \amp\amp\amp \text{Apply the Zero Power Rule}1 \amp\amp\amp \text{Our Solution}\checkmark

subsection.p: Another property we will consider here deals with negative exponents. Again we will solve the following example two ways.

example.title: Negative Exponents

subsection.p:
This example illustrates an important property of exponents. \text{Negative Power Rule of Exponents: } a^{-n}= \frac{1}{a^n} \text{ if } a \neq 0
It is important to note that a negative exponent does not mean the expression is negative.

example.title: Simplify a Fraction with a Negative Exponent
example.p: Simplify. \left(\dfrac{5}{3} \right)^{-2} \amp\amp\amp \text{Negative exponents tell us to take the reciprocal}\left(\dfrac{3}{5} \right)^2 \amp\amp\amp \text{The reciprocal has a positive exponent, now power rule}\dfrac{3^2}{5^2} \amp\amp\amp \text{Evaluate}\dfrac{9}{25} \amp\amp\amp \text{Our Solution}\checkmark

subsection.p: In the example above, we simplified the reciprocal of the fraction by using the method for dividing fractions, \frac{1}{\frac{a}{b}} = 1 \cdot \frac{b}{a} = \frac{b}{a} \amp\amp\amp \text{}
Following is the rule for negative exponents:

historical.title: World View Note
historical.p: Nicolas Chuquet, the French mathematician of the 15th century wrote 12^{1\overline{m}} to indicate 12x^{-1}. This was the first known use of the negative exponent.

subsection.p: We now have the following nine properties of exponents. It is important that we are very familiar with all of them.
